06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:55): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: well, then there's Twitter's page, which screws up ... all menu hotkeys
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:55): i've always found it very strange that browsers *let* pages do that
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:55): (cancel keydowns for major browser hotkeys)
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (23:56): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: this sounds more like a browser fault than a web page fault
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (23:56): the right fix for this stuff is for there to be a way for a web page to say to the UA
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (23:56): "i'd like to handle the following actions {list}"
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (23:56): "please let the user map them however, and tell me when the user has fired one"
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (23:56): that way if you want to use f99 to trigger <bold>, you could
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (23:56): and your UA could persist that preference
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (23:57): and if i want to use <tab> to trigger <bold>, i could, and my UA would persist that preference
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (23:57): please just make that happen :)
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (23:58): a UA today is in control to the extent that it should enable you to tell it "don't pass ctrl-shift-u to the web page"
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (23:59): and "please map <x> to ctrl-shift-u for the web page"
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (23:59): but sadly no UAs do this :(
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (23:59): (well, ignoring accessibility agents)
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:59): well, user keymappings are pretty niche
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:59): not that i'm personally against features that happen to fit my niche, but
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (23:59): users with limited keysets are becoming much more common
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:59): understandable for it not to be the highest priority
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (23:59): not everyone has a 104 key keyboard these days
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (23:59): That sounds like it wouldn't work
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:00): your average found doesn't have one certainly
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:00): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: why not?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:00): What would the page write for help text?
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:00): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: you're already in trouble there with mac keyboards :P
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:00): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: well, if it detects a UA that supports it
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:01): it'd just register events "bold", "underline", etc.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:01): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6: Right, but when there are only two options it's more or less OK
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:01): and then have a link to the UAs help for mapping them
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:01): Most people know if they are using a mac
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:01): i recently dealt w/ a "web app" which insisted i use IE6- or FF3-
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:01): Generally these things that are supposed to be autoconfigured by the UA haven't really worked out
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:01): see also:accesskey
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:02): it's really a bad idea for web pages to be forced to hard code understandings of UAs
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:02): yeah, accesskey was a nice failure
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:02): but part of it was that it was yet another way to capture user keystrokes
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:02): instead of  a way to let users be in control
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:03): user control is often sort of a last-ditch fallback
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:03): a simple mapping of <event, description> for registration should work
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:03): possibly with default mappings
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:03): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6: it's rarely done, let alone done well
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:03): given the choice between "everything works" and "everything's broken, but the user can fix it", the former is almost always better, of course
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:03): the latter becomes the fallback when people can't figure out how to implement the former
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:03): (because, sometimes, it's hard)
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:04): the former only works for 3 months around product launch
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:04): and only in the target environment
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:04): which ceases to be available at month 4
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:04): depends on how competently it's designed
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:04): Users don't want to be "in control" in the sense of having lots of options
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:04): They want to have everything work by default
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:04): and have a simple story to follow when they get stuck
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:04): on a keyboardless device
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:05): how do you want the user to deal w/ sending ctrl-shift-u?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:05): Not "oh you can go to (some UA dependent config screen) and (do something complex with a long list of options)"

06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:05): of course, that can mean having an interface competent enough so that the UA (not the user, whenever possible) can negotiate a workable interface with scripts
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:05): AIUI ctrl-shift-u isn't a webapp feature, it's an OS feature
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:06): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: how is this thing breaking precisely?
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:06): is the app receiving the unicode character and dying because of it?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:06): I would expect webapps not to break OS features, sure
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:06): or is it preventing it from being triggered in the first place?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:06): e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af, very weirdly.
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:06): assumed the latter
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:06): Just like I expect them to work with the compose key or IMEs
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:06): No, it breaks from when it gets Ctrl-Shift-u.
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:06): define breaks more precisely, please?
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:07): is it trying to capture something else? eg. is it seeing the ctrl-u and screaming "underline!" and cancelling the event?
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:07): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6: that would be my bet..

06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:07): not matching keyboard events precisely enough is a very common bug
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:07): Keyboad events are a world of hurt
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:07): that's not webapps fault
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:08): no, it's UA + DOM
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:08): It's a browser/specs problem
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:08): the platform's fault
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:08): generally
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:08): I'm not convinced that DOM3 events makes it better
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:08): in fact that spec seems to be a disaster

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:13): (which also has search these days)

e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:13): an app can have no help

e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:13): i'm mostly asking whether apps generally document these things at all
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (00:14): (as opposed to third party documenters)
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:14): e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af: it's something they should take a hint from desktop apps for
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:14): the practice of putting keyboard shortcuts next to corresponding menu items is as clear as you can get
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:15): and avoids clutter, since it's only visible when you happen to have that menu open
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:15): and avoids the "go read the docs" syndrome (you shouldn't have to read a manual to know what shortcuts are)
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:15): (particularly important because nobody writes manuals :)
